channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Murder at Sea: Captured on Video, but Killers Go Free
item.description: A video shows at least four unarmed men being gunned down in the water. Despite dozens of witnesses, the killings went unreported and remain a mystery.
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA

item.title: Ventimiglia Journal: Migrants’ Journeys Stall in Italy, Near the French Border
item.description: Camps along the Mediterranean coast illustrate divisions between the Italians and the French over managing a border that is theoretically open.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Migrants at a sit-in in Ventimiglia, Italy, last month. The demonstrators had spent the night near the sea at the French-Italian border after being denied entry to France.

item.title: FIFA Sets Feb. 26, 2016, as Date for Election to Replace Sepp Blatter
item.description: Mr. Blatter, the governing body’s departing president, is expected to continue to serve until his successor is named.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: FIFA's headquarters in Zurich. Sepp Blatter, the organization’s departing president, was expected to set a date on Monday for a new presidential election.

item.title: As Banks in Greece Reopen, New Sales Taxes Add to Confusion
item.description: Lenders opened their doors for the first time in three weeks, but with strict limits still in place on the flow of money, the battered economy was far from returning to normal.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN and ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.media:description: A National Bank employee opens the door of a branch in Athens on Monday morning. Greek banks had been closed for three weeks.

item.title: U.N. Moves to Lift Sanctions on Iran After Nuclear Deal
item.description: The resolution, required for the nuclear accord to become effective, sets up a potential showdown over the accord in the United States Congress.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Friendly Fire From U.S. Helicopters Kills Afghan Troops, Officials Say
item.description: The strike in the eastern province of Logar, which killed at least seven Afghan soldiers, is under investigation, an American military spokesman said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: U.S. Embassy in Cuba Reopens After More Than 50 Years
item.description: The opening in Havana on Monday was a watershed moment of transition for the two nations as they lean toward closer diplomatic ties.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists on a bus tour in Havana. More than two years of effort went into restoring relations between the United States and Cuba.

item.title: Turkey Calls Deadly Blast at Suruc, Near Syria, a Terrorist Attack
item.description: An explosion at a cultural center, the cause of which was not immediately clear, killed at least 27 people and wounded 100 others, the Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: KARAM SHOUMALI and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A wounded man after an explosion in Suruc, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Afghanistan, Empires and the Grateful Dead
item.description: Conflict and loss and a broken-down VW Kombi. What a long, strange trip it’s been.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Greece's Costly Health Care Craze
item.description: The various bailout plans to resolve the Greek crisis have overlooked a root cause of the country's troubles.
item.dc:creator: MARTY MAKARY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Obama’s Chance to Revisit Kenya
item.description: America’s president must talk candidly to his counterpart.
item.dc:creator: JOHNNIE CARSON and MARK BELLAMY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Andrew G. Walder on ‘China Under Mao’
item.description: In his latest book, Mr. Walder argues that Mao lurched from crisis to crisis, inspired less by a new vision of Communism than a simplistic understanding of Stalinist ideology.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Andrew G. Walder has written extensively about life in Maoist China.

item.title: The Outlaw Ocean: Murder at Sea: Captured on Video, but Killers Go Free
item.description: A video shows at least four unarmed men being gunned down in the water. Despite dozens of witnesses, the killings went unreported and remain a mystery.
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA
item.media:description: An employee inspected a rifle aboard the Resolution, a floating armory that anchored in the Gulf of Oman.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Qigong Master Said to Be Detained in Murder Case
item.description: Wang Lin, a famous spiritual guru, was detained along with three other men in connection with the kidnapping and death a businessman, according to news reports.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wang Lin, a qigong master, during an interview in Hong Kong in 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Police Detain at Least 4 Over Uniqlo Sex Video
item.description: The Beijing police have detained at least four people on suspicion of uploading or distributing a video of a couple having sex in a Uniqlo fitting room that was widely shared online last week.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A woman posing outside the Uniqlo store in the Sanlitun area of Beijing, where a sex video taken in one of the fitting rooms last week became a viral sensation.

item.title: Russian Town Near Ukraine, Once Quiet, Now Buzzes With Military Activity
item.description: A year after the war started in southeastern Ukraine, the Russian military has largely abandoned efforts to disguise its activities along the border.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Russian military vehicles in a field about six miles from the Ukranian border in August 2014.

item.title: For G.O.P., Pope Francis’ Visit to Congress Comes With Tensions
item.description: Pope Francis has forcefully staked out ideological ground opposite that of Speaker John A. Boehner and his Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: Speaker John A. Boehner at a news conference this month. The pope’s visit will fulfill a long-held dream of Mr. Boehner, who has extended offers to popes for the last 20 years.

item.title: As U.S. and Cuba Relations Warm, Property Claims Issue Is Revived
item.description: The issue is made more difficult by the more than 50 years that have passed since Fidel Castro came to power and began confiscating land and businesses in the name of the revolution.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Amy Rosoff's father, Roy Schechter, at bottom left, in Cuba in 1930 with his immediate family. Morris Schechter, top left, and Jeannette Schechter, center, were forced to abandon their home in the "Country Club" district in Havana.

item.title: U.N. Vote on Iran Nuclear Deal Irks Congress
item.description: The Security Council will hold a vote on potentially lifting sanctions against Iran, before Congress has a chance to debate the terms of the nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Aubrey Morris, British Actor Known for Role in ‘A Clockwork Orange,’ Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Morris’s career spanned more than five decades, but his portrayal of P. R. Deltoid in Stanley Kubrick’s celebrated 1971 film was his most beloved and famous role.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Aubrey Morris in the HBO drama "Deadwood" in 2006.
